cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
the first political society started under british rule in india was
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To determine the first political society that started under British rule in India, we need to consider the historical context of British colonialism in India. The British East India Company established its rule in India during the 18th century, and various political movements and societies began to emerge in response to British policies and governance. One of the earliest political organizations was the Indian National Congress, founded in 1885, but there were earlier societies that aimed to address political issues. 

One significant society that emerged before the Indian National Congress was the "Indian Association," founded in 1876 by Surendranath Banerjee and others in Calcutta (now Kolkata). This association aimed to promote political awareness and advocate for Indian rights under British rule. 

Given this context, the first political society that can be identified as starting under British rule in India is the Indian Association.

Answer: The Indian Association (founded in 1876).

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
the first political society started under british rule in india was
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The first Scientific Society of India was established first in Ghazipur in 1862 by Sir Syed Ahmed Khan for propagating modern Western knowledge of science, technology and industry. It was a departure from the past in the sense that education made a paradigm shift from traditional humanities and related disciplines to the new field of science and agriculture. Some current institution like Technical Education and Research Institute (TERI), part of post-graduate college PG College Ghazipur, in the city, takes their inspiration from that first Society.\n', 'The Free India Society was a political organization of Indian students in England, committed to obtaining the independence of India from British rule.Initially an intellectual group, it became a revolutionary outfit under its founding leader, Madam Bhikaji Cama.\n', 'Filmmaker Satyajit Ray founded the first Indian film society, the Calcutta Film Society in 1947. In 1959, Federation of Film Societies of India was formed as a central organization combining the film societies of Calcutta, Delhi, Bombay (now Mumbai), Madras (now Chennai) and Patna. Satyajit Ray was elected President. In Chennai, in 1981 Chennai Film Society was started by serious film buffs and film institute graduates. M. Sivakumar was its founder secretary and Sasikumar was its founder president. It was active for 15 years with screening of international films, conducting film appreciation courses, meeting up with film makers, screening retrospective of masters and anniversary film festival. It ran a film magazine in Tamil called Salanam for five years. With the advent of DVDs, satellite television channels, and many of its society organizers got active in film making, the Chennai film society slowly disappeared.\n', 'The Indian Empire Society was a London-based lobbying organization, formed in 1930 to promote the cause of the British Empire in India. \n', 'Political consciousness and opposition to British raj in Bengal had grown steadily over the last decades of the 1800s. By 1902, Calcutta had three secret societies working toward the violent overthrow of British rule in India. These included the "Anushilan Samity", founded by a Calcutta student named Satish Chandra Basu with the patronage of the Calcutta barrister Pramatha Mitra, another led by a Bengalee lady by the name of Sarala Devi, and a third one founded by Aurobindo Ghosh. Ghosh was one of the strongest proponents of militant nationalism at the time. Having forsaken a potential career in the Indian Civil Service, Ghosh had returned to India and taken up an academic post under the patronage of the Maharaja of Baroda. Here he came to develop a close relationship with Indian Maratha nationalist Bal Gangadhar Tilak, and through him the nationalist network in Maharashtra. Inspired by the histories of Italian and Irish nationalism, Aurobindo began preparing the grounds and network for an Indian nationalist revolution, in which he found support in Tilak. Aurobindo sought for source of military training to prepare for a revolution in future. His younger brother Barin joined Aurobindo in Baroda. Baroda offered Barin to obtain training in military strategies and armed conflicts.In 1903, Aurobindo Ghosh sent his younger brother Barindra Kumar Ghosh to Calcutta to rally the nascent organisation. By 1905, the controversial 1905 partition of Bengal had a widespread political impact: it stimulated radical nationalist sentiments in the "Bhadralok" community in Bengal, and helped "Anushilan" acquire a support base among of educated, politically conscious and disaffected young in local youth societies throughout Bengal. The works of Aurobindo and his brother Barin Ghosh allowed "Anushilan Samity" to spread through Bengal. "Anushilan" began a program of slowly building a support base, preparing slowly and steadily for a nationalist uprising, on the lines of the Italian "Carbonari".\n', 'The British India Society was set up in 1839 in England primarily as a result of the efforts of William Adam, who had come to India and befriended Ram Mohan Roy. On his return to England he took up India’s cause. Others involved were George Thompson, William Ednis, and Major General Briggs. They organised meetings and enlightened people about conditions in India. In 1841, it started publishing a newspaper named "British Indian Advocate", edited by Professor William Adam\n', 'The Young Bengal, and Jugantar movements and newspapers like Amrita Bazar Patrika led the intellectual development of India. The Calcutta-based Indian National Association and the British Indian Association were the earliest political organisations in India.\n', 'By 1902, Calcutta had three secret societies working toward the violent overthrow of British rule in India. One was founded by Calcutta student Satish Chandra Basu with the patronage of Calcutta barrister Pramatha Mitra, another was led by Bengali woman Sarala Devi and the third was founded by Aurobindo Ghosh. Ghosh was one of the strongest proponents of militant Indian nationalism at the time. By 1905 the work of Aurobindo and his brother, Barin, enabled Anushilan Samity to spread throughout Bengal. Nationalist writings and publications by Aurobindo and Barin, including "Bande Mataram" and "Jugantar", had a widespread influence on Bengal youth. The 1905 partition of Bengal stimulated radical nationalist sentiments in Bengal\'s Bhadralok community, helping Anushilan acquire a support base of educated, politically-conscious and disaffected members of local youth societies. Its program emphasized physical training, training its recruits with daggers and "lathis" (bamboo staffs used as weapons). The Dhaka branch of Anushilan was led by Pulin Behari Das, and branches spread throughout East Bengal and Assam. More than 500 branches were opened in eastern Bengal and Assam, linked by "close and detailed organization" to Pulin\'s headquarters at Dhaka. It absorbed smaller groups in the province, soon overshadowing its parent organisation in Calcutta. Branches of Dhaka Anushilan emerged in Jessore, Khulna, Faridpur, Rajnagar, Rajendrapur, Mohanpur, Barvali and Bakarganj. Estimates of Dhaka Anushilan Samiti\'s reach indicate a membership of 15,000 to 20,000. Within two years, Dhaka Anushilan devolved its aims from the Swadeshi to that of political terrorism.\n', 'Until 1991, over 20 years ago, there was no representation for Hindu students at a campus level and so the first Hindu society, at London School of Economics, was set up to cater for these needs. Although in its early years there was large scale opposition to the creation of Hindu societies, with people arguing that the existing Asian or Indian societies sufficed, NHSF (UK) has now become a firmly established movement.\n', 'The Philatelic Society of India (PSI) was formed in 1897 by a group of, mainly, expatriate Englishmen resident in the country as the first all-India philatelic society. During its first fifty years the society included most of the important Anglo-Indian philatelists and had a particularly strong publications record with two award-winning books. The society meets every first and third Saturday at the Mumbai G.P.O., convened by Dhirubhai Mehta, President, and D.M. Pittie, Hon. Secretary.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To address the question regarding the first political society under British rule in India, we can extract and analyze relevant content from the provided passages. Here’s a breakdown of the passages that may contain unfamiliar concepts or relevant historical context:

1. **Political Organizations and Movements**:
   - **The Free India Society**: This was a political organization of Indian students in England, focused on obtaining independence from British rule. It highlights the role of Indian expatriates in the independence movement, indicating that political consciousness was not limited to India but also present among Indians abroad.
   - **Anushilan Samity**: Founded by Satish Chandra Basu, this secret society aimed at the violent overthrow of British rule. It signifies the emergence of militant nationalism in India and the organized efforts to resist colonial rule. The mention of Aurobindo Ghosh and his influence on radical nationalism provides insight into the ideological underpinnings of such movements.

2. **Early Political Organizations**:
   - **Indian National Association and British Indian Association**: These were among the earliest political organizations in India, indicating the formalization of political activism against British rule. Their establishment marks a significant shift from individual efforts to organized political movements.

3. **British India Society**: Established in 1839 in England, this society aimed to promote awareness about conditions in India. It reflects the transnational nature of the political discourse surrounding India and the involvement of British sympathizers in advocating for Indian causes.

4. **Cultural and Intellectual Movements**:
   - **Young Bengal and Jugantar movements**: These movements contributed to the intellectual development of India and played a role in shaping political thought. They indicate that political activism was intertwined with cultural and intellectual pursuits.

5. **Militant Nationalism**: The passages discuss the rise of militant nationalism, particularly through groups like Anushilan Samity, which sought to prepare for armed resistance against British rule. This aspect is crucial for understanding the broader context of the Indian independence movement.

### Analysis of the Role of Extracted Content:

- **Contextual Understanding**: The extracted content provides a historical backdrop to the political landscape in India during British rule. It illustrates the evolution of political consciousness and the various forms of resistance that emerged, from intellectual societies to militant organizations.
  
- **Interconnectedness of Movements**: The passages highlight how different movements and organizations were interconnected, with influences spanning across regions and even internationally. This interconnectedness is vital for understanding the complexity of the independence movement.

- **Diverse Approaches to Resistance**: The mention of both intellectual and militant approaches to resistance showcases the diversity of thought and strategy among Indian nationalists. This diversity is essential for a nuanced understanding of the struggle for independence.

- **Role of Expatriates**: The involvement of Indians abroad, as seen in the Free India Society, emphasizes that the fight for independence was not confined to the subcontinent but was a global struggle, with support and activism occurring in various parts of the world.

In summary, the extracted content enriches the understanding of the first political society under British rule in India by providing historical context, illustrating the emergence of political consciousness, and highlighting the diverse strategies employed in the struggle for independence. This background knowledge is crucial for answering the original question effectively.

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine the first political society that started under British rule in India, we must consider the historical context of British colonialism and the emergence of political organizations in response to it. The British East India Company established its rule in India during the 18th century, leading to various political movements and societies aimed at addressing grievances against British policies.

1. **Historical Context**: The Indian National Congress, founded in 1885, is often cited as a significant political organization, but it was not the first. Earlier societies laid the groundwork for political activism in India.

2. **Early Political Organizations**: The **Indian Association**, founded in 1876 by Surendranath Banerjee and others in Calcutta, is recognized as one of the earliest political organizations. It aimed to promote political awareness and advocate for Indian rights under British rule. This association marked a shift from individual efforts to organized political movements.

3. **Other Notable Societies**: The **British India Society**, established in 1839 in England, aimed to raise awareness about conditions in India and involved British sympathizers advocating for Indian causes. This reflects the transnational nature of the political discourse surrounding India.

4. **Militant Nationalism**: The emergence of groups like the **Anushilan Samity**, founded by Satish Chandra Basu, signifies the rise of militant nationalism. This organization aimed for the violent overthrow of British rule and highlights the diverse approaches to resistance against colonialism.

5. **Cultural and Intellectual Movements**: Movements such as **Young Bengal** and **Jugantar** contributed to the intellectual development of India, intertwining cultural pursuits with political activism. This indicates that political consciousness was not only a response to colonial rule but also a broader cultural awakening.

6. **Role of Expatriates**: The **Free India Society**, formed by Indian students in England, underscores the global dimension of the independence movement, showing that political consciousness extended beyond the subcontinent.

By synthesizing this information, we can conclude that while the Indian National Congress is often highlighted, the **Indian Association** is a more accurate answer to the question of the first political society started under British rule in India.

### Answer:
The Indian Association (founded in 1876).

To answer the question regarding the first political society that started under British rule in India, we can analyze the provided passages for relevant information about political organizations and movements during that period.

1. **Political Organizations in India**: The passages mention several political organizations that emerged in India during British rule. Notably, the **Indian National Association** and the **British Indian Association** are highlighted as some of the earliest political organizations in India. These organizations played a crucial role in the political landscape of India as they were among the first to mobilize Indian citizens against British rule.

2. **Context of Political Consciousness**: The passages also discuss the growing political consciousness and opposition to British rule, particularly in Bengal, where secret societies like the **Anushilan Samity** were formed. This indicates a rising sentiment among educated Indians to challenge colonial authority, which is a significant aspect of the political landscape during British rule.

3. **Foundational Movements**: The **Young Bengal** movement and the **Jugantar** newspapers are mentioned as influential in the intellectual development of India. These movements contributed to the political awakening among the youth and played a role in shaping nationalist sentiments.

4. **Historical Significance**: The **British India Society**, established in 1839 in England, aimed to promote awareness about the conditions in India and advocate for reforms. While it was based in England, it reflects the early efforts to address Indian issues and can be seen as part of the broader context of political activism related to British rule.

5. **Summary of Insights**: The earliest political societies in India under British rule include the **Indian National Association** and the **British Indian Association**. These organizations were foundational in mobilizing political action and fostering a sense of nationalism among Indians. The emergence of secret societies like the **Anushilan Samity** further illustrates the growing political consciousness and the desire for independence.

### Conclusion
Based on the contextual analysis of the passages, the first political society that started under British rule in India is most likely the **Indian National Association**, established in 1867, as it is recognized as one of the earliest organized political movements aimed at advocating for Indian interests and rights against British colonial rule. The **British Indian Association**, formed earlier in 1851, also played a significant role in this context. Both organizations laid the groundwork for future political movements leading to India's independence.

', 'Filmmaker Satyajit Ray founded the first Indian film society, the Calcutta Film Society in 1947. In 1959, Federation of Film Societies of India was formed as a central organization combining the film societies of Calcutta, Delhi, Bombay (now Mumbai), Madras (now Chennai) and Patna. Satyajit Ray was elected President. In Chennai, in 1981 Chennai Film Society was started by serious film buffs and film institute graduates. M. Sivakumar was its founder secretary and Sasikumar was its founder president. It was active for 15 years with screening of international films, conducting film appreciation courses, meeting up with film makers, screening retrospective of masters and anniversary film festival. It ran a film magazine in Tamil called Salanam for five years. With the advent of DVDs, satellite television channels, and many of its society organizers got active in film making, the Chennai film society slowly disappeared.
', 'The Indian Empire Society was a London-based lobbying organization, formed in 1930 to promote the cause of the British Empire in India. 
', 'Political consciousness and opposition to British raj in Bengal had grown steadily over the last decades of the 1800s. By 1902, Calcutta had three secret societies working toward the violent overthrow of British rule in India. These included the "Anushilan Samity", founded by a Calcutta student named Satish Chandra Basu with the patronage of the Calcutta barrister Pramatha Mitra, another led by a Bengalee lady by the name of Sarala Devi, and a third one founded by Aurobindo Ghosh. Ghosh was one of the strongest proponents of militant nationalism at the time. Having forsaken a potential career in the Indian Civil Service, Ghosh had returned to India and taken up an academic post under the patronage of the Maharaja of Baroda. Here he came to develop a close relationship with Indian Maratha nationalist Bal Gangadhar Tilak, and through him the nationalist network in Maharashtra. Inspired by the histories of Italian and Irish nationalism, Aurobindo began preparing the grounds and network for an Indian nationalist revolution, in which he found support in Tilak. Aurobindo sought for source of military training to prepare for a revolution in future. His younger brother Barin joined Aurobindo in Baroda. Baroda offered Barin to obtain training in military strategies and armed conflicts.In 1903, Aurobindo Ghosh sent his younger brother Barindra Kumar Ghosh to Calcutta to rally the nascent organisation. By 1905, the controversial 1905 partition of Bengal had a widespread political impact: it stimulated radical nationalist sentiments in the "Bhadralok" community in Bengal, and helped "Anushilan" acquire a support base among of educated, politically conscious and disaffected young in local youth societies throughout Bengal. The works of Aurobindo and his brother Barin Ghosh allowed "Anushilan Samity" to spread through Bengal. "Anushilan" began a program of slowly building a support base, preparing slowly and steadily for a nationalist uprising, on the lines of the Italian "Carbonari".
', 'The British India Society was set up in 1839 in England primarily as a result of the efforts of William Adam, who had come to India and befriended Ram Mohan Roy. On his return to England he took up India’s cause. Others involved were George Thompson, William Ednis, and Major General Briggs. They organised meetings and enlightened people about conditions in India. In 1841, it started publishing a newspaper named "British Indian Advocate", edited by Professor William Adam
', 'The Young Bengal, and Jugantar movements and newspapers like Amrita Bazar Patrika led the intellectual development of India. The Calcutta-based Indian National Association and the British Indian Association were the earliest political organisations in India.
', 'By 1902, Calcutta had three secret societies working toward the violent overthrow of British rule in India. One was founded by Calcutta student Satish Chandra Basu with the patronage of Calcutta barrister Pramatha Mitra, another was led by Bengali woman Sarala Devi and the third was founded by Aurobindo Ghosh. Ghosh was one of the strongest proponents of militant Indian nationalism at the time. By 1905 the work of Aurobindo and his brother, Barin, enabled Anushilan Samity to spread throughout Bengal. Nationalist writings and publications by Aurobindo and Barin, including "Bande Mataram" and "Jugantar", had a widespread influence on Bengal youth. The 1905 partition of Bengal stimulated radical nationalist sentiments in Bengal's Bhadralok community, helping Anushilan acquire a support base of educated, politically-conscious and disaffected members of local youth societies. Its program emphasized physical training, training its recruits with daggers and "lathis" (bamboo staffs used as weapons). The Dhaka branch of Anushilan was led by Pulin Behari Das, and branches spread throughout East Bengal and Assam. More than 500 branches were opened in eastern Bengal and Assam, linked by "close and detailed organization" to Pulin's headquarters at Dhaka. It absorbed smaller groups in the province, soon overshadowing its parent organisation in Calcutta. Branches of Dhaka Anushilan emerged in Jessore, Khulna, Faridpur, Rajnagar, Rajendrapur, Mohanpur, Barvali and Bakarganj. Estimates of Dhaka Anushilan Samiti's reach indicate a membership of 15,000 to 20,000. Within two years, Dhaka Anushilan devolved its aims from the Swadeshi to that of political terrorism.
', 'Until 1991, over 20 years ago, there was no representation for Hindu students at a campus level and so the first Hindu society, at London School of Economics, was set up to cater for these needs. Although in its early years there was large scale opposition to the creation of Hindu societies, with people arguing that the existing Asian or Indian societies sufficed, NHSF (UK) has now become a firmly established movement.
', 'The Philatelic Society of India (PSI) was formed in 1897 by a group of, mainly, expatriate Englishmen resident in the country as the first all-India philatelic society. During its first fifty years the society included most of the important Anglo-Indian philatelists and had a particularly strong publications record with two award-winning books. The society meets every first and third Saturday at the Mumbai G.P.O., convened by Dhirubhai Mehta, President, and D.M. Pittie, Hon. Secretary.
']

Task Description:
Please extract content from these passages that can help enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities.
consolidate these contents, and analyze how the selected information may impact the improvement of the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages. The focus will be on identifying key political societies and their historical significance in the context of British rule in India. Here’s a summary of the relevant content:

### Extracted Information:

1. **Indian National Association and British Indian Association**: These were among the earliest political organizations in India, indicating the emergence of political consciousness and organized efforts against British rule.

2. **Anushilan Samity**: Founded by Satish Chandra Basu and others, this secret society aimed at the violent overthrow of British rule. It illustrates the radicalization of political movements in Bengal and the influence of nationalist sentiments, especially after the 1905 partition of Bengal.

3. **Free India Society**: Established by Indian students in England, this organization was committed to India's independence from British rule, evolving from an intellectual group to a revolutionary outfit.

4. **British India Society**: Founded in 1839 in England, this society aimed to promote awareness about the conditions in India and advocate for reforms, showing early efforts to address British colonial policies.

5. **Political Consciousness in Bengal**: The growth of political consciousness and opposition to British rule in Bengal during the late 1800s, leading to the formation of several secret societies, indicates a significant shift in societal attitudes towards colonial governance.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

1. **Understanding Cause and Effect**: The passages illustrate how specific events (e.g., the 1905 partition of Bengal) led to increased political activism and the formation of societies aimed at opposing British rule. This helps the model understand the causal relationships between historical events and the emergence of political movements.

2. **Identifying Patterns**: By analyzing the formation of various societies and their objectives, the model can identify patterns in political mobilization, such as the transition from intellectual discourse to revolutionary action. This enhances the model's ability to infer future trends based on historical precedents.

3. **Contextual Analysis**: The information provides context about the socio-political environment of India under British rule, allowing the model to make more nuanced inferences about the motivations behind the formation of political societies and their strategies.

4. **Complex Interactions**: The interplay between different organizations (e.g., the influence of the Free India Society on Indian nationalism) can be analyzed to understand how various groups contributed to a larger movement for independence. This complexity aids the model in reasoning about multifaceted historical narratives.

5. **Historical Significance**: Recognizing the significance of early political organizations helps the model appreciate the foundational elements of modern political movements in India, thereby improving its ability to draw parallels and make logical connections between past and present political dynamics.

### Conclusion:

The extracted content provides a rich basis for enhancing the model's causal reasoning and logical inference capabilities. By understanding the historical context, the relationships between events, and the motivations of various political entities, the model can better analyze and infer the implications of political actions and movements, both in historical and contemporary contexts.

Here is an answer generated by a language model with the reasoning process.
question:
the first political society started under british rule in india was
answer:
Reasoning process: 
To determine the first political society that started under British rule in India, we need to consider the historical context of British colonialism in India. The British East India Company established its rule in India during the 18th century, and various political movements and societies began to emerge in response to British policies and governance. One of the earliest political organizations was the Indian National Congress, founded in 1885, but there were earlier societies that aimed to address political issues. 

One significant society that emerged before the Indian National Congress was the "Indian Association," founded in 1876 by Surendranath Banerjee and others in Calcutta (now Kolkata). This association aimed to promote political awareness and advocate for Indian rights under British rule. 

Given this context, the first political society that can be identified as starting under British rule in India is the Indian Association.

Answer: The Indian Association (founded in 1876).

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To determine the first political society that started under British rule in India, we must consider the historical timeline and the emergence of political organizations in response to British colonialism. The British East India Company established its rule in India during the 18th century, leading to various political movements aimed at addressing grievances against British policies.

1. **Historical Context**: The Indian National Congress, founded in 1885, is often recognized as a significant political organization, but it was not the first. Prior to this, several societies emerged to advocate for Indian rights and political awareness.

2. **Key Societies**:
   - **Indian Association**: Founded in 1876 by Surendranath Banerjee and others in Calcutta, this association aimed to promote political awareness and advocate for Indian rights under British rule. It is often cited as one of the earliest political organizations in India.
   - **Indian National Association**: Established in 1876, this organization also played a crucial role in mobilizing political consciousness among Indians.
   - **British Indian Association**: Formed in 1851, this was another early political organization that sought to address the concerns of Indians under British governance.

3. **Emergence of Political Consciousness**: The late 19th century saw a significant rise in political consciousness, particularly in Bengal, where organizations like the Anushilan Samity emerged, advocating for more radical approaches to achieving political goals.

4. **Causal Relationships**: The formation of these societies can be seen as a direct response to the oppressive policies of British rule, illustrating a clear cause-and-effect relationship between colonial governance and the rise of political activism.

5. **Influence of Early Organizations**: The early political societies laid the groundwork for future movements, including the Indian National Congress, by fostering a sense of unity and purpose among Indians.

### Conclusion:
Based on the historical context and the emergence of political organizations, the first political society that can be identified as starting under British rule in India is the **Indian Association**, founded in 1876. This society played a pivotal role in advocating for Indian rights and raising political awareness among the populace.

### Answer:
The Indian Association (founded in 1876).

- The **Indian National Association** and the **British Indian Association** are among the earliest political societies formed in India under British rule.
- The **Anushilan Samity** and other secret societies were significant in the context of political activism but may not fit the definition of formal political societies.

knowledge enhanced inference process:
Answer:

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

To determine the first political society that started under British rule in India, we must consider the historical context of British colonialism and the emergence of political organizations in response to it. The British East India Company established its rule in India during the 18th century, leading to various political movements and societies advocating for Indian rights and political awareness.

While the **Indian National Congress** was founded in 1885 and is often recognized as a significant political organization, earlier societies also played crucial roles in the political landscape. One notable organization is the **Indian Association**, founded in 1876 by Surendranath Banerjee and others in Calcutta (now Kolkata). This association aimed to promote political awareness and advocate for Indian rights under British rule.

However, additional passages indicate that the **Indian National Association** and the **British Indian Association** were also among the earliest political organizations in India. The Indian National Association, founded in 1867, was significant in promoting political consciousness and advocating for reforms. The British Indian Association, established in 1851, also contributed to the political discourse during British rule.

Furthermore, while societies like the **Anushilan Samity** were politically motivated and aimed at the violent overthrow of British rule, they may not fit the definition of formal political societies in the same way as the Indian National Association or British Indian Association.

In summary, the earliest political societies under British rule include the **British Indian Association** (founded in 1851) and the **Indian National Association** (founded in 1867), with the **Indian Association** (founded in 1876) being another significant early organization.

**Answer:** The British Indian Association (founded in 1851) and the Indian National Association (founded in 1867) are among the earliest political societies started under British rule in India.

The British India Society was set up in 1839 in England primarily as a result of the efforts of William Adam, who had come to India and befriended Ram Mohan Roy. On his return to England he took up India’s cause. Others involved were George Thompson, William Ednis, and Major General Briggs. They organised meetings and enlightened people about conditions in India. In 1841, it started publishing a newspaper named "British Indian Advocate", edited by Professor William Adam
The Young Bengal, and Jugantar movements and newspapers like Amrita Bazar Patrika led the intellectual development of India. The Calcutta-based Indian National Association and the British Indian Association were the earliest political organisations in India.
By 1902, Calcutta had three secret societies working toward the violent overthrow of British rule in India. One was founded by Calcutta student Satish Chandra Basu with the patronage of Calcutta barrister Pramatha Mitra, another was led by Bengali woman Sarala Devi and the third was founded by Aurobindo Ghosh. Ghosh was one of the strongest proponents of militant Indian nationalism at the time. By 1905 the work of Aurobindo and his brother, Barin, enabled Anushilan Samity to spread throughout Bengal. Nationalist writings and publications by Aurobindo and Barin, including "Bande Mataram" and "Jugantar", had a widespread influence on Bengal youth. The 1905 partition of Bengal stimulated radical nationalist sentiments in Bengal's Bhadralok community, helping Anushilan acquire a support base of educated, politically-conscious and disaffected members of local youth societies. Its program emphasized physical training, training its recruits with daggers and "lathis" (bamboo staffs used as weapons). The Dhaka branch of Anushilan was led by Pulin Behari Das, and branches spread throughout East Bengal and Assam. More than 500 branches were opened in eastern Bengal and Assam, linked by "close and detailed organization" to Pulin's headquarters at Dhaka. It absorbed smaller groups in the province, soon overshadowing its parent organisation in Calcutta. Branches of Dhaka Anushilan emerged in Jessore, Khulna, Faridpur, Rajnagar, Rajendrapur, Mohanpur, Barvali and Bakarganj. Estimates of Dhaka Anushilan Samiti's reach indicate a membership of 15,000 to 20,000. Within two years, Dhaka Anushilan devolved its aims from the Swadeshi to that of political terrorism.
Until 1991, over 20 years ago, there was no representation for Hindu students at a campus level and so the first Hindu society, at London School of Economics, was set up to cater for these needs. Although in its early years there was large scale opposition to the creation of Hindu societies, with people arguing that the existing Asian or Indian societies sufficed, NHSF (UK) has now become a firmly established movement.
The Philatelic Society of India (PSI) was formed in 1897 by a group of, mainly, expatriate Englishmen resident in the country as the first all-India philatelic society. During its first fifty years the society included most of the important Anglo-Indian philatelists and had a particularly strong publications record with two award-winning books. The society meets every first and third Saturday at the Mumbai G.P.O., convened by Dhirubhai Mehta, President, and D.M. Pittie, Hon. Secretary.
